1.title: Simplr Router
1.headline: Simplr Router
1.body:
A small and effective routing solution for Web Components 


  
    Follow Guides 
  
    Browse Docs

2.title: Simplr Router
2.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
2.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

3.title: Simplr Router
3.headline: Small
3.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

4.title: Simplr Router
4.headline: Easy to transition into
4.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

5.title: Simplr Router
5.headline: Web Component focused
5.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

6.title: Simplr Router
6.headline: Customizable
6.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

7.title: Simplr Router
7.headline: Performant
7.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

50.title: Recipes: Lazy loading
50.headline: Bundlers
50.body:
Due to the nature of the import being in code, most bundlers should be able to grasp onto the import statement
and bundle it correctly, even if the file gets renamed.

e.title: Getting started: Using a starter
e.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
e.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

f.title: Getting started: Using a starter
f.headline: Initial setup
f.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

g.title: Getting started: Using a starter
g.headline: Installing the router
g.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

h.title: Getting started: Using a starter

j.title: Getting started: Using a starter
j.headline: Creating your initial routing

k.title: Getting started: Using a starter
k.headline: Adding views
k.body:
Next we will want to do some actual routing. This requires a few steps: 

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

3i.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3i.headline: Initial setup
3i.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

3j.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3j.headline: Installing the router
3j.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

3k.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3k.headline: Configuring History API fallback

3m.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3m.headline: Creating your initial routing

3n.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3n.headline: Adding views
3n.body:
Next we will want to do some actual routing. This requires a few steps: 

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

3o.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3o.headline: Create a view to navigate to

3p.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3p.headline: Add it as a route

3q.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3q.headline: Create a link to navigate to the page

3r.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3r.headline: Next steps
3r.body:
You're now all set to start building your application on top of Simplr Router. For more configuration
options and recipes, check out the recipes  section. For a thorough look into the actual API
behing Simplr Router, check out the docs .

3z.title: Recipes: Lazy loading
3z.headline: Bundlers
3z.body:
Due to the nature of the import being in code, most bundlers should be able to grasp onto the import statement
and bundle it correctly, even if the file gets renamed.

4a.headline: Performant
4a.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

6a.title: Simplr Router
6a.headline: Web Component focused
6a.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

6b.headline: Customizable
6b.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.
